title: ChIP-seq: Transcription Factor & Histone Binding Analysis with Input Controls
description: Comprehensive ChIP-seq analysis pipeline for identifying protein-DNA interactions with matched input controls for accurate background correction. Identify where transcription factors bind and histone modifications occur across the genome.
content:
ğŸ§¬ ChIP-seq: Protein-DNA Interaction Analysis

Map Where Proteins Bind to DNA with Precision

Chromatin Immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing (ChIP-seq) reveals where proteins interact with DNA across your genome. By enriching DNA bound to your protein of interest and comparing against matched input controls, you can pinpoint regulatory elements, transcription factor binding sites, and chromatin modifications that control gene expression.

ğŸ¯ Why Input Controls Are Essential

Input controls are critical for accurate ChIP-seq analysis. Here's why:

ğŸ“Š Background Correction

  • ğŸ§ª Chromatin accessibility bias: Some genomic regions are naturally more accessible and get enriched regardless of your antibody

  • ğŸ”¬ Amplification bias: PCR and sequencing introduce technical artifacts that must be normalized

  • ğŸ§¬ Copy number variation: Regions with more DNA copies appear enriched without true binding

âœ… What Input Controls Do

  • Measure background signal: Input DNA (chromatin without immunoprecipitation) represents the baseline

  • Enable statistical testing: Compare ChIP vs Input to identify true binding sites

  • Control for technical variation: Account for differences in DNA preparation and sequencing

Without input controls, you cannot distinguish true protein binding from technical artifacts!

ğŸ”¬ Experimental Design

Standard ChIP-seq Workflow:

  1. Crosslink proteins to DNA - Formaldehyde fixes proteins to their binding sites

  2. Chromatin fragmentation - Sonication breaks DNA into ~200-500bp fragments

  3. Immunoprecipitation - Antibody pulls down your protein + bound DNA

  4. Library preparation - Both ChIP and Input DNA are prepared for sequencing

  5. Paired sequencing - ChIP samples AND matched input controls

Critical Requirements:

  • Each ChIP sample MUST have a matched input control

  • Input controls should be from the same batch of cells

  • Biological replicates improve statistical power (minimum 2 recommended)

ğŸ” What This Pipeline Does

Quality Control & Preprocessing

  • ğŸ“Š FASTQC: Assess read quality, adapter content, duplication levels

  • âœ‚ï¸ Trimming: Remove adapters and low-quality bases

  • ğŸ“ˆ Alignment QC: Check mapping rates and library complexity

Peak Calling with Input Controls

  • ğŸ¯ MACS2: Industry-standard peak caller that uses your input controls for background modeling

  • ğŸ”¬ Statistical testing: Identifies regions significantly enriched in ChIP vs Input

  • ğŸ“Š Narrow peaks: Sharp binding sites for transcription factors

  • ğŸ“ˆ Broad peaks: Extended regions for histone modifications

Downstream Analysis

  • ğŸ§¬ Peak annotation: Which genes are near your binding sites?

  • ğŸ” Motif discovery: DNA sequence patterns in binding sites

  • ğŸ“Š Consensus peaks: Reproducible peaks across replicates

  • ğŸ“ˆ Coverage tracks: Visualize binding in genome browsers

ğŸ§¬ Reference Genome Selection

Choose the genome matching your organism:

  • ğŸ§‘ Human: GRCh38/hg38 (recommended) or GRCh37/hg19 (legacy)

  • ğŸ­ Mouse: GRCm39/mm39 (recommended) or GRCm38/mm10 (legacy)

  • ğŸ”¬ Model organisms: Yeast, fly, worm, zebrafish - all supported

ğŸ“‹ Sample Sheet Format

Your CSV file defines ChIP samples and their matching input controls:

sample,fastq_1,fastq_2,antibody,control
H3K27ac_rep1,chip_r1_R1.fq.gz,chip_r1_R2.fq.gz,H3K27ac,INPUT_rep1
H3K27ac_rep2,chip_r2_R1.fq.gz,chip_r2_R2.fq.gz,H3K27ac,INPUT_rep2
INPUT_rep1,input_r1_R1.fq.gz,input_r1_R2.fq.gz,,
INPUT_rep2,input_r2_R1.fq.gz,input_r2_R2.fq.gz,,

Column Descriptions:

  • sample: Unique identifier for each sample

  • fastq_1: Read 1 file (R1)

  • fastq_2: Read 2 file (R2) - leave empty for single-end

  • antibody: Name of ChIP antibody (empty for input controls)

  • control: Name of matching input sample for this ChIP sample

ğŸ“Š Expected Results

Peak Files

  • ğŸ“„ BED files: Genomic coordinates of binding sites

  • ğŸ“Š Summit files: Peak centers (highest enrichment)

  • ğŸ“ˆ BigWig tracks: Coverage visualization for genome browsers

Quality Reports

  • ğŸ“Š MultiQC: Comprehensive quality report across all samples

  • ğŸ¯ FRiP scores: Fraction of reads in peaks (quality metric)

  • ğŸ“ˆ Correlation plots: Reproducibility between replicates

Biological Insights

  • ğŸ§¬ Peak annotations: Which genes are regulated?

  • ğŸ” Motif analysis: DNA binding preferences

  • ğŸ“Š Consensus peaks: High-confidence binding sites
